Lived in Newtown my whole life. Taught in Newtown for years (not at Sandy Hook but down the street). If somebody said this to my face, I would likely get arrested for assault. I know many of the families affected by this. This sort of stupidity is like your parents being murdered, then somebody telling you that they never actually existed because they were supposed to have a gym membership, but the gym in town didn't have any records of them.
Kindergarten through 8th grade. Mostly the middle schoolers.

Went to Sandy Hook Elementary growing up, and was a teacher in Newtown until this school year. At my school, things are pretty much normal and you don't notice any difference on the surface. It's little things that let you know something has happened. If there's a siren in the distance, you can see their attention go up and they look around at each other. There's obvious unspoken fear there. If an administrator goes over the loudspeaker and doesn't sound quite right - a little too intense or worried - they notice right away and wonder what's going on. They've had several lock-ins and lockdowns since Sandy Hook, and it always brings out a wash of emotions that are typically held back. Several break down and cry, or rock slowly to themselves from their position on the floor (everyone's on the floor in a lockdown). Several had relatives that were killed, and many had friends or siblings' friends from outside of school that were killed. One of my students' little sister was killed, and another one had an aunt killed in the shooting. It's a pretty close-knit community, so pretty much everyone has some connection to a victim. I have a friend that went to school with Adam Lanza before he was pulled out to be homeschooled. We're moving on, but it's definitely taken its toll on the community, particularly the children.
